headline: DEREK LAWRENSON: This year's Players Championship feels more like Skegness than Sawgrass and with strong winds forecast, there is no sign of it getting better any time soon
author: Derek Lawrenson for the Daily Mail
sentences: The 25-year-old has won two of his last three events, including the Arnold Palmer Invitational on Sunday, and made it to four under with four to play, the same mark as Johnson, evidently focused once more now he has made his mind up not to join the Saudis.

American Daniel Berger, showing no ill-effects from his surprising final round collapse at the Honda Classic a fortnight ago, got within one shot of the first-round lead posted by Tommy Fleetwood and Tom Hoge with two holes to complete.

+4
View gallery
Chief Championship referee Gary Young said 'we seem to be suffering from bad luck'
+4
View gallery
Dustin Johnson shields himself from the rain in the first round of the Players Championship
The golf?

+4
View gallery
Assistant Superintendent, John Michael Clark, tends to water on a green during the first round
'We seem to be suffering from bad luck,' said chief referee Gary Young with considerable understatement.

'We've battled through tough conditions and squeegeed the greens as much as we can, but at this point there's no window where the rain is going to let up and there's lightning on the way,' said Young.
It is a tribute to the 100-strong green staff and almost as many volunteers that four hours of play were actually possible on Friday morning before they finally conceded defeat to Mother Nature.
Defending champion Justin Thomas made it to two under after 15, but familiar failings with a wedge left playing partner Rory McIlroy one over and clearly exasperated.
How sad for the 45,000 sell-out crowd, allowed through the gates this week for the first time in three years and advised to head for the exits long before lunchtime.
Two more who coped well were Dustin Johnson and Scottie Scheffler, who has taken his game to a different level since his impressive Ryder Cup debut in September.
Asked what was working well in his game, he settled for a one-word answer that will serve every player well for however long this tournament goes on: 'Patience.'

+4
View gallery
Rory McIlroy was clearly exasperated after failings with a wedge left him one over in Florida
A couple of Englishmen did manage to finish.
As the rain cascaded down at this cursed edition of the Players, it was hardly surprising no one was taking him up on his offer.
The sole ticket tout on the road leading to the Stadium Course here held up a sign with a forlorn message: 'Discount on Golf.'
How typical that there had not been a single weather delay on the PGA Tour this year until they reached this flagship event.
From Tampa to Miami, St Petersburg to Orlando, they have been enjoying weather like you are supposed to get in Florida.
Students of Roman history will know all about that date and now even golfers have cause to beware the Ides of March.
But up here in the north-east, a band of heavy rain and thunderstorms have formed an unrelenting line.
Strong winds are forecast for Saturday and bone-chilling temperatures for Sunday.
This has felt more like Skegness than Sawgrass and it is not getting any better.
For the past two days the meteorological map has been a study in black humour.
Last year's runner-up Lee Westwood shot 73 while Matt Fitzpatrick carded a 74.
Justin Rose (above) got in 14 holes and reached an encouraging two under.
By the suspension, 2.5in of rain had fallen in less than 24 hours.
'Tuesday is a possibility at this point,' conceded Young.
Never mind the first Monday finish since 2005.
